testInfo.name: Gesamtfragenkatalog zum Test „Leben in Deutschland“ und zum „Einbürgerungstest“

questions.germanQuestion: In Deutschland dürfen Menschen offen etwas gegen die Regierung sagen, weil …
questions.englishQuestion: In Germany, people can openly say something against the government because …

options.englishOption: there is freedom of religion here.
people have the right to vote.
there is freedom of speech here.

questions.notes: Germany protects the right to free speech under the Basic Law (Grundgesetz).
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Meinungsfreiheit' directly translates to 'freedom of opinion,' a core principle in democratic societies.

resources.description: More about freedom of speech in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: In Deutschland können Eltern bis zum 14. Lebensjahr ihres Kindes entscheiden, ob es in der Schule am …
questions.englishQuestion: In Germany, parents can decide until their child is 14 years old whether it participates in …
questions.notes: In Germany, religion classes are not mandatory and parents can decide if their children will attend them.
questions.learningTechniques: Think of 'Religionsunterricht' (religion class) as a choice, reflecting Germany's respect for religious freedom.

resources.description: Overview of the education system in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Deutschland ist ein Rechtsstaat. Was ist damit gemeint?
questions.englishQuestion: Germany is a constitutional state. What does that mean?

options.germanOption: Alle Einwohnerinnen/Einwohner und der Staat müssen sich an die Gesetze halten.
options.englishOption: All residents and the state must follow the laws.

options.germanOption: Der Staat muss sich nicht an die Gesetze halten.
options.englishOption: The state does not have to follow the laws.

options.germanOption: Nur Deutsche müssen die Gesetze befolgen.
options.englishOption: Only Germans must follow the laws.

questions.notes: A Rechtsstaat (constitutional state) ensures that the state and all its citizens are bound by law.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember 'Rechtsstaat' by associating 'Recht' with 'right' or 'law.'

resources.description: What is a Rechtsstaat?

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Recht gehört zu den Grundrechten in Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which right is one of the fundamental rights in Germany?
questions.notes: Freedom of speech is a fundamental right in Germany, guaranteed by the Basic Law.
questions.learningTechniques: Meinungsfreiheit is a core democratic right, linking 'Meinung' (opinion) and 'Freiheit' (freedom).

resources.description: More about fundamental rights in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wahlen in Deutschland sind frei. Was bedeutet das?
questions.englishQuestion: Elections in Germany are free. What does that mean?

options.germanOption: Man darf Geld annehmen, wenn man dafür eine bestimmte Kandidatin/einen bestimmten Kandidaten wählt.
options.englishOption: You can accept money in exchange for voting for a specific candidate.

options.germanOption: Nur Personen, die noch nie im Gefängnis waren, dürfen wählen.
options.englishOption: Only people who have never been in prison are allowed to vote.

options.germanOption: Die Wählerin/der Wähler darf bei der Wahl weder beeinflusst noch zu einer bestimmten Stimmabgabe gezwungen werden und keine Nachteile durch die Wahl haben.
options.englishOption: The voter must not be influenced or forced to vote in a certain way and should not suffer any disadvantages from the election.

questions.notes: In Germany, elections are free, meaning that voters can make their decisions without being forced or influenced, and their choice should not result in any disadvantages.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'freie Wahlen' (free elections) in Germany emphasize independence and fairness in voting.

resources.description: More about the principles of free elections in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie heißt die deutsche Verfassung?
questions.englishQuestion: What is the name of the German constitution?
questions.notes: The German constitution is called 'Grundgesetz,' which translates to 'Basic Law.' It was established after World War II and serves as the foundation of German law.
questions.learningTechniques: Think of 'Grundgesetz' as the fundamental (or 'ground') law that underpins all other laws in Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the German Basic Law.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Recht gehört zu den Grundrechten, die nach der deutschen Verfassung garantiert werden? Das Recht auf …
questions.englishQuestion: Which right is one of the fundamental rights guaranteed by the German constitution? The right to …
questions.notes: The German constitution guarantees fundamental rights such as freedom of belief and conscience.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Glaubensfreiheit' and 'Gewissensfreiheit' are essential rights in a democratic society, ensuring personal freedom in beliefs.

resources.description: Learn more about fundamental rights in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was steht nicht im Grundgesetz von Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: What is not stated in the Basic Law of Germany?

options.germanOption: Die Würde des Menschen ist unantastbar.
Alle sollen gleich viel Geld haben.
options.englishOption: Everyone should have the same amount of money.

options.germanOption: Jeder Mensch darf seine Meinung sagen.
Alle sind vor dem Gesetz gleich.
options.englishOption: Everyone is equal before the law.

questions.notes: The German Basic Law does not state that everyone should have the same amount of money. It focuses on fundamental rights like dignity, freedom of expression, and equality before the law.
questions.learningTechniques: Think about how the Grundgesetz emphasizes human rights and personal freedoms, not economic equality.

resources.description: Overview of the Basic Law in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Grundrecht gilt in Deutschland nur für Ausländerinnen/Ausländer? Das Grundrecht auf …
questions.englishQuestion: Which fundamental right in Germany applies only to foreigners? The right to …
questions.notes: In Germany, the right to asylum is a fundamental right that specifically applies to foreigners.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Asyl' is the right granted to those seeking protection in Germany, reflecting the country's commitment to human rights.

resources.description: Learn more about asylum rights in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was ist mit dem deutschen Grundgesetz vereinbar?
questions.englishQuestion: What is compatible with the German Basic Law?
questions.notes: The German Basic Law forbids practices such as corporal punishment, torture, and the death penalty. However, fines (Geldstrafe) are compatible with the law.
questions.learningTechniques: Associate 'Geldstrafe' with monetary penalties, which are legal and enforceable under the Basic Law, unlike more severe forms of punishment.

resources.description: Details about German criminal law and penalties.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie wird die Verfassung der Bundesrepublik Deutschland genannt?
questions.englishQuestion: What is the constitution of the Federal Republic of Germany called?
questions.notes: The constitution of Germany is officially known as the 'Grundgesetz' or 'Basic Law,' which has governed the country since 1949.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Grundgesetz' literally translates to 'Basic Law,' emphasizing the fundamental legal framework of Germany.

resources.description: Overview of the German Basic Law.

questions.germanQuestion: Eine Partei im Deutschen Bundestag will die Pressefreiheit abschaffen. Ist das möglich?
questions.englishQuestion: A party in the German Bundestag wants to abolish freedom of the press. Is that possible?

options.germanOption: Ja, wenn mehr als die Hälfte der Abgeordneten im Bundestag dafür sind.
options.englishOption: Yes, if more than half of the members of the Bundestag are in favor.

options.germanOption: Ja, aber dazu müssen zwei Drittel der Abgeordneten im Bundestag dafür sein.
options.englishOption: Yes, but two-thirds of the members of the Bundestag must be in favor.

options.germanOption: Nein, denn die Pressefreiheit ist ein Grundrecht. Sie kann nicht abgeschafft werden.
options.englishOption: No, because freedom of the press is a fundamental right. It cannot be abolished.

options.germanOption: Nein, denn nur der Bundesrat kann die Pressefreiheit abschaffen.
options.englishOption: No, because only the Bundesrat can abolish freedom of the press.

questions.notes: Freedom of the press is a fundamental right protected by the German constitution and cannot be abolished, even by a majority in the Bundestag.
questions.learningTechniques: Recall that 'Pressefreiheit' is one of the essential democratic rights in Germany, protected under the Basic Law.

resources.description: Overview of press freedom in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Im Parlament steht der Begriff 'Opposition' für …
questions.englishQuestion: In parliament, the term 'opposition' stands for …

options.germanOption: die Fraktion mit den meisten Abgeordneten.
options.englishOption: the faction with the most members of parliament.

options.germanOption: alle Parteien, die bei der letzten Wahl die 5%-Hürde erreichen konnten.
options.englishOption: all parties that were able to pass the 5% threshold in the last election.

options.germanOption: alle Abgeordneten, die nicht zu der Regierungspartei/den Regierungsparteien gehören.
options.englishOption: all members of parliament who do not belong to the ruling party/parties.

questions.notes: In a parliamentary system, the opposition consists of all members of parliament who are not part of the ruling government or ruling parties.
questions.learningTechniques: Think of 'Opposition' as the group that opposes the current government or ruling parties in parliament.

resources.description: Overview of the role of opposition in the German parliamentary system.

questions.germanQuestion: Meinungsfreiheit in Deutschland heißt zum Beispiel, dass ich …
questions.englishQuestion: Freedom of expression in Germany means, for example, that I …

options.germanOption: Passanten auf der Straße beschimpfen darf.
options.englishOption: may insult passersby on the street.

options.germanOption: meine Meinung im Internet äußern kann.
options.englishOption: can express my opinion on the internet.

options.germanOption: Nazi-, Hamas- oder Islamischer Staat-Symbole öffentlich tragen darf.
options.englishOption: may publicly display Nazi, Hamas, or Islamic State symbols.

options.germanOption: meine Meinung nur dann äußern darf, solange ich der Regierung nicht widerspreche.
options.englishOption: may express my opinion only as long as I do not contradict the government.

questions.notes: Freedom of expression in Germany allows individuals to express their opinions, including online, but it does not protect hate speech or the use of symbols from banned organizations like Nazi groups.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Meinungsfreiheit' guarantees the right to express opinions freely, but within the limits of the law, especially regarding hate speech and extremist symbols.

resources.description: Learn more about freedom of expression in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was verbietet das deutsche Grundgesetz?
questions.englishQuestion: What does the German Basic Law prohibit?
questions.notes: The German Basic Law explicitly prohibits forced labor, protecting individual freedom in work and profession.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Zwangsarbeit' is a violation of human rights, and the German constitution ensures freedom from such practices.

resources.description: More about labor rights in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wann ist die Meinungsfreiheit in Deutschland eingeschränkt?
questions.englishQuestion: When is freedom of expression restricted in Germany?

options.germanOption: bei der öffentlichen Verbreitung falscher Behauptungen über einzelne Personen
options.englishOption: when publicly spreading false statements about individuals
when expressing opinions about the federal government

questions.notes: Freedom of expression in Germany is a fundamental right, but it is limited in cases where it infringes on the rights of others, such as spreading false statements about individuals.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that freedom of expression is protected but not absolute, especially in cases of defamation or spreading false information.

resources.description: More about freedom of speech laws in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Die deutschen Gesetze verbieten …
questions.englishQuestion: German laws prohibit …

options.germanOption: Ungleichbehandlung der Bürgerinnen und Bürger durch den Staat.
options.englishOption: unequal treatment of citizens by the state.

questions.notes: German laws prohibit unequal treatment of citizens by the state, ensuring equality and protection under the law.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the fact that 'Ungleichbehandlung' is prohibited, ensuring equality for all citizens in the eyes of the state.

resources.description: More about anti-discrimination laws in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Grundrecht ist in Artikel 1 des Grundgesetzes der Bundesrepublik Deutschland garantiert?
questions.englishQuestion: Which fundamental right is guaranteed in Article 1 of the Basic Law of the Federal Republic of Germany?
questions.notes: Article 1 of the German Basic Law states that human dignity is inviolable. This is the cornerstone of all fundamental rights in Germany.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that Article 1 of the Basic Law focuses on 'Menschenwürde' (human dignity), which is considered the highest principle.

resources.description: Learn more about the Basic Law's Article 1 and human dignity in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was versteht man unter dem Recht der 'Freizügigkeit' in Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: What is meant by the right of 'freedom of movement' in Germany?

options.germanOption: Man darf sich seinen Wohnort selbst aussuchen.
options.englishOption: You are allowed to choose your place of residence.

options.germanOption: Man darf sich für eine andere Religion entscheiden.
options.englishOption: You can choose a different religion.

options.germanOption: Man darf sich in der Öffentlichkeit nur leicht bekleidet bewegen.
options.englishOption: You are allowed to move in public only lightly dressed.

questions.notes: The right to 'Freizügigkeit' in Germany refers to the ability to choose where you live, a key aspect of personal freedom.
questions.learningTechniques: Link 'Freizügigkeit' with the freedom to move and settle freely within the country.

resources.description: Learn more about the right to freedom of movement in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Eine Partei in Deutschland verfolgt das Ziel, eine Diktatur zu errichten. Sie ist dann …
questions.englishQuestion: A party in Germany pursues the goal of establishing a dictatorship. It is then …

options.englishOption: oriented towards the rule of law.

questions.notes: Any political party in Germany that aims to establish a dictatorship is considered 'verfassungswidrig' (unconstitutional) because it contradicts the democratic principles enshrined in the Basic Law.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'verfassungswidrig' refers to actions or goals that go against the constitution, such as the pursuit of a dictatorship.

resources.description: Learn more about the constitutional law in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches ist das Wappen der Bundesrepublik Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which is the coat of arms of the Federal Republic of Germany?
questions.notes: The coat of arms of Germany is a significant national symbol. It typically depicts an eagle.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that the German coat of arms features an eagle, which has been a symbol of Germany for centuries.

resources.description: Learn more about the coat of arms of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was für eine Staatsform hat Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: What form of government does Germany have?
questions.notes: Germany is a federal republic, meaning it is a democratic state without a monarch, ruled by elected representatives.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that Germany is a 'Republik,' emphasizing its democratic governance structure.

resources.description: Learn more about the government system of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: In Deutschland sind die meisten Erwerbstätigen …
questions.englishQuestion: In Germany, most employed people are …

options.germanOption: selbstständig mit einer eigenen Firma tätig.
bei einer Firma oder Behörde beschäftigt.
options.englishOption: employed by a company or government agency.

questions.notes: In Germany, the majority of employed people work for companies or government agencies rather than being self-employed or working in small family businesses.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the fact that most employment in Germany is structured around companies and public institutions.

resources.description: Learn more about employment structures in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie viele Bundesländer hat die Bundesrepublik Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: How many federal states does the Federal Republic of Germany have?
questions.notes: Germany is made up of 16 federal states (Bundesländer), each with its own government.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember the number 16 when thinking about the structure of Germany's federal system.

resources.description: Learn more about the federal states of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was ist kein Bundesland der Bundesrepublik Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which is not a federal state of the Federal Republic of Germany?
questions.notes: Elsass-Lothringen (Alsace-Lorraine) is not a federal state of Germany. It is a region that historically changed hands between France and Germany but is currently part of France.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Elsass-Lothringen' is a region in France, not a federal state of Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the federal states of Germany.
Learn more about the region of Alsace-Lorraine.

questions.germanQuestion: Deutschland ist …
questions.englishQuestion: Germany is …

options.englishOption: a democratic and social federal state.
a social and socialist federal state.

questions.notes: Germany is defined as a democratic and social federal state in its constitution, ensuring both democratic governance and social welfare.
questions.learningTechniques: Link Germany's system with both democracy and a strong social welfare structure.

resources.description: Learn more about the political system of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Deutschland ist …
questions.englishQuestion: Germany is …
questions.notes: Germany is a federal state, meaning it has a division of powers between the federal government and individual states (Bundesländer).
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on Germany's structure as a 'Bundesstaat,' or federal state, with shared power between national and state governments.

resources.description: Learn more about the federal structure of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wer wählt in Deutschland die Abgeordneten zum Bundestag?
questions.englishQuestion: Who elects the members of the Bundestag in Germany?
questions.notes: The members of the Bundestag, Germany's federal parliament, are elected by the eligible voting population in free and fair elections.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that in a democracy like Germany, the power to elect representatives lies with the people ('wahlberechtigte Volk').

resources.description: Learn more about the Bundestag and its election process.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Tier ist das Wappentier der Bundesrepublik Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which animal is the emblem of the Federal Republic of Germany?
questions.notes: The eagle ('Adler') is the national emblem of Germany, symbolizing strength and freedom.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that the eagle has historically been a symbol of power and sovereignty in Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the national symbols of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was ist kein Merkmal unserer Demokratie?
questions.englishQuestion: Which is not a feature of our democracy?
questions.notes: Press censorship is not a feature of democracy. Instead, democracy is characterized by regular elections, freedom of speech, and the presence of multiple political parties.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the principles of democracy, which oppose censorship and support free expression.

resources.description: Learn more about the features of democratic systems.

questions.germanQuestion: Die Zusammenarbeit von Parteien zur Bildung einer Regierung nennt man in Deutschland …
questions.englishQuestion: The collaboration of parties to form a government in Germany is called …
questions.notes: In Germany, when multiple political parties collaborate to form a government, it is called a 'Koalition' (coalition).
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Koalition' refers to the partnership of different parties working together to govern.

resources.description: Learn more about coalitions in German politics.

questions.germanQuestion: Was ist keine staatliche Gewalt in Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which is not a state authority in Germany?
questions.notes: In Germany, the state powers are divided into the legislative, executive, and judiciary branches. The press is free and not considered a state authority.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that the press is independent of state authority and acts as a watchdog in democratic systems.

resources.description: Learn more about the separation of powers in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Welche Aussage ist richtig? In Deutschland …
questions.englishQuestion: Which statement is correct? In Germany …

options.germanOption: sind Staat und Religionsgemeinschaften voneinander getrennt.
options.englishOption: state and religious communities are separate.

options.germanOption: ist der Staat abhängig von den Religionsgemeinschaften.
options.englishOption: the state depends on religious communities.

options.germanOption: bilden Staat und Religionsgemeinschaften eine Einheit.
options.englishOption: state and religious communities form a unity.

questions.notes: In Germany, there is a clear separation between state and religion, ensuring that religious institutions do not control or form the state.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the principle of secularism in Germany, which separates state functions from religious influences.

resources.description: Learn more about the relationship between state and religion in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was ist Deutschland nicht?
questions.englishQuestion: What is Germany not?
questions.notes: Germany is a democracy, a constitutional state, and a welfare state, but it is not a monarchy.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the fact that Germany is a republic with democratic and social principles, not a monarchy.

resources.description: Learn more about the political structure of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Womit finanziert der deutsche Staat die Sozialversicherung?
questions.englishQuestion: How does the German state finance social security?
questions.notes: Germany finances its social security system primarily through 'Sozialabgaben,' which are social contributions made by employees and employers.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Sozialabgaben' are the key financial source for Germany's extensive social security system.

resources.description: Learn more about the social security system in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Welche Maßnahme schafft in Deutschland soziale Sicherheit?
questions.englishQuestion: Which measure creates social security in Germany?
questions.notes: In Germany, social security is primarily achieved through the health insurance system ('Krankenversicherung'), which ensures access to healthcare for all citizens.
questions.learningTechniques: Associate 'Krankenversicherung' with the concept of social security, which ensures that health-related needs are met for everyone.

resources.description: Learn more about health insurance and social security in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie werden die Regierungschefinnen/Regierungschefs der meisten Bundesländer in Deutschland genannt?
questions.englishQuestion: What are the heads of government in most federal states in Germany called?
questions.notes: In Germany, the head of government in most federal states is called 'Ministerpräsidentin' or 'Ministerpräsident,' which is equivalent to 'Minister-President.'
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Ministerpräsident' refers to the political leader of a German federal state, similar to a governor in other federal systems.

resources.description: Learn more about the political structure of German federal states.

questions.germanQuestion: Die Bundesrepublik Deutschland ist ein demokratischer und sozialer …
questions.englishQuestion: The Federal Republic of Germany is a democratic and social …
questions.notes: Germany is a federal state ('Bundesstaat'), where power is divided between the federal government and individual states.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that Germany is a 'Bundesstaat' (federal state), meaning power is shared between the federal and state governments.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's political system.

questions.germanQuestion: Was hat jedes deutsche Bundesland?
questions.englishQuestion: What does every German federal state have?
questions.notes: Each German federal state has its own government responsible for managing certain areas such as education and law enforcement.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that every German state ('Bundesland') has its own government, unlike areas like foreign policy, which are handled federally.

resources.description: Learn more about the structure of German states.

questions.germanQuestion: Mit welchen Worten beginnt die deutsche Nationalhymne?
questions.englishQuestion: What are the opening words of the German national anthem?

options.englishOption: Joy, beautiful spark of the gods …

questions.notes: The German national anthem starts with the words 'Einigkeit und Recht und Freiheit' (Unity and justice and freedom).
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that the German national anthem emphasizes core values like unity and freedom from the very first words.

resources.description: Learn more about the German national anthem.

questions.germanQuestion: Warum gibt es in einer Demokratie mehr als eine Partei?
questions.englishQuestion: Why are there more than one party in a democracy?

options.germanOption: weil dadurch die unterschiedlichen Meinungen der Bürgerinnen und Bürger vertreten werden
options.englishOption: because it allows the different opinions of citizens to be represented

options.germanOption: damit Bestechung in der Politik begrenzt wird

questions.notes: In a democracy, having multiple parties ensures that the diverse opinions of the population are represented in the political system.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that a core principle of democracy is the representation of various opinions, which is achieved by having multiple political parties.

resources.description: Learn more about the role of political parties in a democracy.

questions.germanQuestion: Wer beschließt in Deutschland ein neues Gesetz?
questions.englishQuestion: Who passes a new law in Germany?
questions.notes: In Germany, new laws are passed by the parliament, known as the Bundestag, which is the legislative branch of government.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the fact that the legislative power to pass laws rests with the parliament (Bundestag) in Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the legislative process in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wann kann in Deutschland eine Partei verboten werden?
questions.englishQuestion: When can a party be banned in Germany?

options.germanOption: wenn ihr Wahlkampf zu teuer ist
options.englishOption: if its election campaign is too expensive

options.germanOption: wenn sie gegen die Verfassung kämpft
options.englishOption: if it fights against the constitution

options.germanOption: wenn sie Kritik am Staatsoberhaupt äußert
options.englishOption: if it criticizes the head of state

options.germanOption: wenn ihr Programm eine neue Richtung vorschlägt
options.englishOption: if its program suggests a new direction

questions.notes: A party can be banned in Germany if it works against the democratic order or the constitution, as determined by the Federal Constitutional Court.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the principle that political parties in Germany must adhere to democratic principles; otherwise, they risk being banned.

resources.description: Learn more about the legal framework for banning parties in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wen kann man als Bürgerin/Bürger in Deutschland nicht direkt wählen?
questions.englishQuestion: Who cannot be directly elected by citizens in Germany?
questions.notes: In Germany, the Federal President is elected by the Federal Assembly, not directly by the citizens.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the fact that while many positions are directly elected in Germany, the Federal President is chosen by the Federal Assembly.

resources.description: Learn more about the German electoral system.

questions.germanQuestion: Zu welcher Versicherung gehört die Pflegeversicherung?
questions.englishQuestion: Which type of insurance includes long-term care insurance?
questions.notes: Long-term care insurance in Germany is part of the social insurance system, which also includes health, unemployment, and pension insurance.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that care insurance ('Pflegeversicherung') is a component of Germany's comprehensive social insurance system.

resources.description: Learn more about social insurance in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Der deutsche Staat hat viele Aufgaben. Welche Aufgabe gehört dazu?
questions.englishQuestion: The German state has many responsibilities. Which is one of them?

options.germanOption: Er versorgt alle Einwohnerinnen und Einwohner kostenlos mit Zeitungen.
options.englishOption: It provides all residents with free newspapers.

questions.notes: One of the German state's main responsibilities is infrastructure development, including the construction of roads and schools.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the state's role in infrastructure, such as building public roads and schools, as key responsibilities.

resources.description: Learn more about the functions of the German state.

questions.germanQuestion: Der deutsche Staat hat viele Aufgaben. Welche Aufgabe gehört nicht dazu?
questions.englishQuestion: The German state has many responsibilities. Which is not one of them?

options.germanOption: Er bezahlt für alle Staatsangehörigen Urlaubsreisen.
options.englishOption: It pays for vacations for all citizens.

questions.notes: While the German state is involved in social benefits, cultural support, and promoting sports, it does not pay for citizens' vacations.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the responsibilities the state does not take on, like personal vacation costs, to understand the limits of state involvement.

resources.description: Learn more about the social responsibilities of the German state.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Organ gehört nicht zu den Verfassungsorganen Deutschlands?
questions.englishQuestion: Which body is not one of Germany's constitutional organs?
questions.notes: The constitutional organs of Germany include institutions like the Bundesrat and the Federal President, but not a citizens' assembly.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that Germany's constitutional organs are formal institutions, unlike a citizens' assembly, which is not part of the structure.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's constitutional organs.

questions.germanQuestion: Wer bestimmt in Deutschland die Schulpolitik?
questions.englishQuestion: Who determines education policy in Germany?
questions.notes: Education policy in Germany is primarily determined by the federal states ('Bundesländer'), which have their own regulations and systems.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that education in Germany is decentralized, with each federal state responsible for its own policies and school systems.

resources.description: Learn more about the education system in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Die Wirtschaftsform in Deutschland nennt man …
questions.englishQuestion: The economic system in Germany is called …
questions.notes: Germany's economic system is called a 'soziale Marktwirtschaft' (social market economy), which combines a free market with social policies to ensure fair competition and welfare.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the term 'soziale Marktwirtschaft,' which emphasizes both market freedom and social welfare measures.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's social market economy.

questions.germanQuestion: Zu einem demokratischen Rechtsstaat gehört es nicht, dass …
questions.englishQuestion: A democratic constitutional state does not include …

options.germanOption: Menschen sich kritisch über die Regierung äußern können.
options.englishOption: people can express criticism of the government.

options.germanOption: Menschen von einer Privatpolizei ohne Grund verhaftet werden.
